Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2012 12:39PM 33skidoo wrote: There have been some   clinical trials to determine whether zometa is an effective CANCER treatment.  I believe that so far those trials have not supported that position, and that the only FDA approved use for zometa is to strenghthen the bones which are depleted of calcium by hormonal treatments.  I would not rely on zometa as a cancer treatment.  There are other hormonal treatments that you could try such as tamoxifen, aromasin and arimidex.  Megace and estradiol treatments are also sometiimes used for hormonal positive cancers.   If you are unhappy with the communication you are having with your onc you can either attempt to educate yourself, schedule a DISCUSSION appointment with your doctor, or get a second opinion.  I've done all those things.  You can too.

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2012 09:16AM - edited Jan 22, 2012 09:17AM by 33skidoo I'm glad you are going to give it another try with your current onc.  I think they tread on thin ice trying to find out how much information each patient can handle.  I didn't want much information at all in the beginning, I just wanted someone to tell me what to do.  As I got more used to the idea of my stage IV diagnosis, I wanted to know more and more.  After my discussion with my onc we have been communicating more effectively. This site has some good educational materials regarding advanced or metastatic breast cancer as well as information regarding the various sub-types of breast cancer.  There are many, and each has different recommended treatments.  If you are up for something a little more detailed, the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has guidelines for cancer treatment.  They publish 2 versions, one for patients, and one for doctors.  Go to their site (www.nccn.org) and look around to find the download page.  They don't check to see if you are a doctor, so you can download the physician guidelines for breast cancer treatment if you want to. There are MANY different treatments available to treat breast cancer; it's a bit of an art.  Reasonable doctors can differ in their treatment recommendations.  I felt better after looking at them because it helped me understand that despite progression, there are still many options for treatment. If you feel that it may make you anxious, just avoid it.   Many people prefer to find a doctor they trust and let him or her worry about the treatment plan.

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2010 09:43PM 33skidoo wrote: I am ER+/PR- stage IV from the get-go.  Initial treatment was Tamoxifen, radiation, and surgical reconstruction of my back.  I have bone-only mets. Got to remission/NED.  Was switched to Aromasin after I became post-menopausal.  Evenually had some progression, got radiation and switched to faslodex.  Tumor markers are back down to normal range.  So I have to say that hormonals have been working for me.  My status has never been reported in percentages (and I have asked). I have tried to research the whole PR- issue and have found very little.  I did find a research article that said that lapatinib improves event-free survival for ER+PR-Her2- patients. In MBC, lapatinib improved EFS in patients with HER2-amplified tumors and also in those with tumors that were HER2 negative, ER positive, and PR weak. In MBC, lapatinib improved EFS in patients with HER2-amplified tumors and also in those with tumors that were HER2 negative, ER positive, and PR weak. Up to 25% of women with breast cancer have amplification of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2), a finding that is associated with a poor prognosis. Identification of HER2 as a target for therapy has been validated by the use of trastuzumab and lapatinib. In contrast, agents targeting epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) have not shown significant activity in breast cancer. The role that EGFR plays in the pathogenesis of breast cancer is not clear. Lapatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor of both EGFR and HER2. Prior studies have suggested that a relationship exists between loss of progesterone receptor (PR) in estrogen receptor (ER)-positive disease and higher expression of HER2 and/or EGFR. In addition, some data suggest that patients who have triple-negative breast cancer, (tumors that lack ER, PR, and HER2 amplification) have higher EGFR levels and enhanced sensitivity to EGFR-targeted agents. The present study was a retrospective analysis of patients from EGF30001, a phase III study investigating the use of lapatinib plus paclitaxel as first-line therapy for patients with HER2-negative or HER2-status-unknown metastatic breast cancer (MBC). The purpose of the present analysis was to evaluate ER, PR, HER2, and EGFR expression and correlate the expression with benefit from lapatinib. Of the 579 patients enrolled in EGF30001, 493 patients provided tissue available for testing. Among these, 86 patients had tumors showing HER2 amplification and 407 patients did not. Lapatinib was found to improve median event-free survival (EFS) in HER2-amplified disease and in patients with either ER- or PR-positive disease. However, the improvement was greater in the group with hormone receptor-negative disease. In the patients without HER2 amplification, lapatinib showed no benefit based solely on that biomarker. Subgroup analysis of patients with HER2-nonamplified, ER-positive breast cancer showed that median EFS improved based on expression of PR. For the group classified as PR-strong, there was no improvement of EFS. Some improvement was noted for the group classified as PR-weak, and there was possible antagonism for the PR-negative group. The subgroup of patients with triple-negative breast cancer did not show improvement of EFS with the addition of lapatinib. Overall, EGFR expression did not predict for improved median EFS with the addition of lapatinib. In the use of targeted agents, patient selection is of critical importance. This study provides additional evidence supporting the existence of a relationship between the HER family and hormone-receptor signaling.

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2013 02:42PM 33skidoo wrote: I've been ignoring this thread for awhile.  Just wasn't in the right frame of mind to do it.  I have done this twice before, years ago.  We've lost so many, it makes sense to start this thread over from time to time. I was stage IV from the get go.  Went to the doctor after ignoring what I thought was garden variety back pain for some time.  It got to the point where I could no longer ignore it.  An MRI revealed metastatic bone tumors to T11 and T12.  T12 was almost completely gone as well as collapsed and the tumor was wrapped around my spinal cord.  No wonder it hurt ;^).  It took a good while to determine where the cancer had originated as my mammograms had been clear and we could not feel a tumor in my extremely dense breasts.  But the consulting surgeon thought he could feel something, and sure enough was able to locate a tumor deep in the tissue. I had major reconstructive surgery to my back which necessitated a seven level spinal fusion with pedicle screws and rods.  The surgery was a piece of cake compared to what I had been through prior to the MRI and I was walking soon with the help of physical therapy.  Staging studies showed more tumors in hip and ribs.  Went on Tamoxifen which was working well on the cancer but caused a crazy-big ovarian cyst which along with adhesions compressed my ureters and caused kidney problems.  Cured that problem with total abdominal hysterectomy and had ovaries removed while I was at it.  The gyn onc insisted on doing the large incision to reduce the chance of spilling the contents of the ovarian cyst (which was extremely hot on the PET scan and it was suspicious for mets).  Due to the adhesions, he popped it anyway and ended up doing a bowel resection to boot.  Good thing the pathology was all benign! I went back to work after that, working as a public defender of sorts.   I was able to do that for a little over 3 years before it got to be too much in light of my various physical issues and need for ongoing medical treatment.   Retirement was a bit of an adjustment but I no longer miss it.  The removal of that stress actually helped my overall condition and I feel better even though things appear to be a bit worse on paper. I'm more than 5 years out from the stage IV diagnosis and feel hopeful that I'll be around for a good while longer.  Since my diagnosis I have been able to travel to visit my family members that live out of state and went to a fabulous B&B in New Mexico with one of my sisters.  I still plan to see the aurora borealis, but have been scandalized over the expense.   This site has saved my sanity.  I love it and the people I've met here.  Thanks a lot!!!

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2012 06:47PM 33skidoo wrote: I see that your "status" changed from triple positive to ER+/PR- no Her2 status.  Has something changed?    Where are you going for your second opinion?  There are a number of perfectly valid treatments for metastatic breast cancer, and as long as you are on any reasonable treatment protocol I think that most doctors would advise waiting to see if it works.  But I had the impression that you are her2 postive and NOT getting herceptin, which is disturbing, and that you have had recent progression or concern that you might have progression.  When I have gone for second opinons, I was not switching doctors or treatments at that time, I was gathering information.    Clearly it is possible that you might just click with the doctor you see for your second opinion and decide to switch.  But you might leave the consultation feeling a lot better about the treatment you are getting currently.   Or you might have a disparity between the doctors opinions and decide to go for a third opinon.   Sorry to say that it is a process. Go in armed with your list of questions, don't bad mouth your current doctor, tell the new doc that you are crawling out of your hole of shock and doom and are ready to hear about your options.

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2014 07:32PM - edited Sep 8, 2014 07:35PM by 33skidoo Frances, sounds like you should get a 2nd opinion!  It's so important to have confidence in your doctor and your treatment plan.  A second (or 3rd or even 4th) opinion can give you the information you need to evaluate and participate in your treatment plan.   A source I discovered to educate myself is the NCCN website.  NCCN is a consortium of cancer treatment professionals who come up with guidelines and spreadsheets on the current standard of care for many different types of cancer.  To get access to the treatment guidelines that are provided to doctors, you have to register as a doctor, but they don't check.  Reading those guidelines helped me to see that my doctor was on top of the most current treatment recommendations.

Posts.Content: 33skidoo wrote: I've been trying to find out more information on our specific subtype of cancer, and am wondering to what degree our experiences have been similar to or different from one another.  My story....  Had increasing back pain over several years.  Assumed it was the family bad back, and never bothered to have it looked at because I know the drill with that.  Then had 3 lymph nodes swell painfully.  Somewhat freaked out, but had lymph nodes swell due to illness in past, so I decided to give it two weeks to see if they went down.  They WERE going down, but my back suddenly got significantly worse.  That got me into doctor.  Turned out to be metastatic disease in my T11 & T12 vertebrae.  Admitted to hospital with unstable back fracture, then search was on for the primary.  Found 1.25 cm tumor deep in my VERY dense breast.  Turned up more  mets in ribs, pelvis and femoral neck.  The breast tumor was by far the smallest.  Two of the three swollen nodes had gone down, but the 3rd DID have bc. Had radiation, surgery, tamoxifen and zometa.  Got to hear the R word. Tamoxifen caused huge endometrioma (ovarian cyst).  Surgery to remove it revealed extreme endometriosis.  Neutered. Now switched to Aromasin because of side effects of tamoxifen and post-menopausal status. Currently doing well. I've been wondering if the endometriosis caused the breast cancer. Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2010 11:09AM - edited Apr 2, 2010 11:15AM by 33skidoo Jenny, I had extensive mets in my spine, along with others in my pelvis, ribs and femur.  I was diagnosed when I ended up in the hospital with collapsed vertebrae and tumor wrapped completely around my spinal cord.  At the time, I honestly believed that I would not leave the hospital.  A sister-in-law is an oncology nurse and frankly thought the same.  The consulting neurosurgeon did not wantn to do any surgery beyond a biopsy.  But my onc was GREAT.  He told me that although stage IV breast cancer is considered to be "incurable", there were many effective treatments that could push back the disease, and that some people did indeed achieve remission.  He explained to me that "palliative" does not mean pain meds only and wait for death.  Palliative care is ANY treatment that does not have curative intent.  It includes reconstructive surgery, bone stabilization surgery, radiation to knock back the disease and/or for pain relief, systematic treatment for sympton relief, etc.  As my cancer was hormonal, my treatment plan was to have reconstructive surgery and radiation on my back, removed the primary from my breast (that's how we got the initial pathology), and hormonal treatment for the systematic disease.  After an initial scary "flare" when treatment first started, I achieved "remission" within several months.  I'm 2 1/2 years out from my initial stage IV diagnosis and living a normal life.  I do still need pain meds as the extensive bone mets have left a lasting impression, but it is quite manageable. Don't feel stupid.  I did too.  How could I be stage IV from the get go when I lived a healthy lifestyle and got my mammograms?  Remeber that any symptoms that you may have had were NONSPECIFIC.  It could have been anything.  Sure, I had back pain, but that can be very normal for a middle-aged woman with a family history of back problems.  Sure, my mammograms were normal, but I didn't know that mammograms, while better than nothing, miss a lot of stuff, especially if one has dense breasts.  I didn't have a "lump" that I could feel in my breast.  My primary was relatively small and BURIED deep within my dense breasts.  I did have a problem with lymph node in my armpit flaring up from time to time, but I had asked about it and was told that it was normal for them to pop up from time to time, it was probably a reaction to some infection and would go away (and did).  The vast majority of breast lumps are benign. We don't know all that much about cancer.  Who knows what caused it to appear?  Did I not wash my fruits and veggies enough?  Did I eat meat from animals that had been treated by hormones?  Did I not properly handle a pesticide I applied to the garden?  Was it just plain bad luck and I got my cancer due to a sporadic genetic mutation?  Who knows?  All we can do is get by the best we can. Please follow the advice of the other compassionate and experienced women in our forum.  They have learned their lessons the hard way and you can benefit from their wisdom.  A stage IV diagnosis is a very hard thing to get your head wrapped around, and it will take some time.  Give yourself a break.  Pick yourself up, get another opinion, interview doctors and find one you like and trust.  Get some antianxiety and/or antidepressant meds.  You will feel  much better once your treatment plan is in place. Hugs. Claire

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2010 09:18PM 33skidoo wrote: There is a difference between "addiction" and "dependence".  Dependence is the physical reliance our bodies develop for the pain meds.  It occurs with most people who take opiod pain meds.  It is NOT the same thing as addiction.  Addiction is destructive behavior seeking and using drugs in a manner not intended or as prescribed (frequently with serious consequences... lying, cheating, stealing).  We also develop "tolerance" to the meds and require higher and higher doses over time to achieve the same effect.  I have never felt "high" when using the meds for legitimate pain relief.  I do try to use prescription pain meds as little as possible so that I have saved some tolerance for down the line, when I want the big guns to work for heavy-duty pain.  We are the poster-children for under-treated pain.  We should take them as needed without fear of addiction.  And if a few "terminally ill" patients get addicted, who the hell cares?

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2010 10:42PM 33skidoo wrote: I have spinal bone mets and herniated discs.  My discs are causing much more problems than the mets.  I did a series of epidural steroid injections which DID include sedation (and fasting).  I got stuck with an afternoon appointment for my last shot and opted to go without the sedation so that I could eat.  It DID hurt for a little while to go without the sedation but I saved a ton of $$ and didn't suffer thru fasting (I get REALLY cranky when I am hungry). The shots DID help temporarilly (for several weeks each).  Having completed the series, insurance will not pay for another series for at least 6 months.  My back is somewhat improved, but I'm nowhere near pain free.  If I could guarantee success with surgery, looking back I think that I probably should have had the surgery.  However, since there is no guarantee of success and because I have already had extensive back surgery (7-level fusion), I am content with my choice. YMMV.

Posts.Content: 33skidoo wrote: 5 years ago today I was diagnosed with Stage IV cancer, origin unknown.  Went in for an MRI for my extreme back pain.  Discovered collapsed vertebrae with tumor wrapped around the spinal cord.  Admitted to hospital that day due to spinal cord compression and the adventure began.  Eventually discovered small breast tumor and had an excisional biopsy.  Transferred to large hospital with a cancer center and had radiation to spine and a 7-level spinal fusion.  3 weeks in the hospital.  When first diagnosed I thought I would never ever get out of there!  But I did.  And was able to walk short distances.  Now my ability to walk is unimpaired.  Do have some residual balance problems, but can't complain.  Finished the radiation which was interrupted for the surgery.  Put on Tamoxifen and Zometa. Later had PET/CT which revealed highly metabolic lesion near a ginormous ovarian cyst.  Referred to an oncologic gyncologist due to possibility of mets in that area.  Had abdominal hysterectomy with the vertical incision 8^(! to make sure that the cyst be removed without popping it and spreading potentially cancerous cells throughout abdomen.  Fat chance, he popped it anyway!!!  Turned out to not be cancerous but crazy bloom of endometriosis probably due to the Tamoxifen.  Surgeon cleaned it out, got rid of numerous adhesions and I made another good recovery.  I have had progression of bone mets from time to time, more radiation and later developed "innumerable" lung mets.  Did a clinical trial at Johns Hopkins for vaccine.  First chemo for lung mets (Cytoxan, methotrexate and 5-fluorouracil) didn't work, but next chemo (Abraxane) has been working.  Lung mets are fewer and smaller!  This time last year I thought I was on the downhill slide, but have been doing well after chemo change.  Thinking the vaccine may have helped. Feeling good and hope to live awhile longer.  Thanks to this site, have kept my mental health on an even keel.  Thanks for all your support and advice.  Edited for spelling, punctuation & grammar. Dx 8/2007, IDC, 1cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 1/1 nodes, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2012 12:47PM 33skidoo wrote: When you do get your mom in to see a doctor, make sure that her pain is addressed.  Cancer patients are frequently undertreated for pain.  A wise old nurse once told me that pain is like a forest fire... relatively easy to put out when small, but when out-of-control it takes quite a lot to put it out.  I find that taking an extended release pain med every few hours regardless of my pain level keeps the overall level of pain tamped down.  If that doesn't do enough, then I take additional immediate release pain meds to help.  If I forget to take my regular pain meds my pain quickly spirals out of control.  If she doesn't have any prescription pain meds now and over the counter pain med should help some.

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2010 06:02PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:22AM by 33skidoo Suzy, I was stage IV from the get go.  Had 2 vertebrae eaten up (pretty much completely) by the bone mets which grew out of the bone and around my spinal cord.  The first neurosurgeon was Mr. Doom and Gloom.  Acted like there was no point to surgery and didn't want to do it.  My medical oncologist, God bless him, told me that non-oncs don't have a clue about cancer and tend to misjudge the value of surgery.  Surgery may be warranted to make the patient more comfortable or more functional.  There are some studies that seem to  indicate that removal of the primary tumor(s) in the breast can favorably impact survival.  I had an "excisional biopsy"/lumpectomy with good margins, back reconstructive surgery, some radiation, got my ovaries out (I was pre-menopausal) and made it to remission/NED.  I'm still doing well more than 3 years since my diagnosis.  I've since run into other non-oncology doctors who acted like I am circling the drain, but I'm here to tell you they are idiots.  Listen to the oncologist, and get a second or even third opinion.  Make sure than any pain your sister has is treated aggressively.  If she doesn't tell them she is hurting they will assume that she isn't.  There is no valid reason to leave discomfort untreated.  I do find that I feel better if I am more active.  Water aerobics are the best!!!   You might also consider getting her a port.  It's much easier than being poked all the time.  If she gets a port, try to get a "power port" so they can use it instead of veins for her scans

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2011 01:36AM 33skidoo wrote: usafmom, Your mets diagnosis is overwhelming.  Your head WILL spin for some time before you start to digest all you have read.  But it will happen.  Don't get hung up on "statistics".  You are not a statistic, you are an individual, and statistics do not apply to individuals.  It turns out that breast cancer is many many different diseases, and may even be unique to individuals.  There are many effective treatments out there, and you will find one.  I believe that you will feel much better emotionally and physically once you have a treatment plan in place and it starts to work.  As a triple positive there are many treatment options for you and you are likely to live for many more years.  Remember to live.  Get out.  Do stuff.  Hang in there!  And if you are feeling anxious and depressed there is no shame in taking meds to combat that.  Better living thru chemistry!

Posts.Content: 33skidoo wrote: Here's a radiation trial that I thought looked pretty interesting.  It's at NIH in Bethesda MD.  Not a huge committment for time, so very doable for out-of-towners.  Information cut and pasted from cancer.gov: A Phase II Study of Hypofractionated Highly Conformal Radiation With Helical Tomotherapy for Extra-Cranial Oligometastases NCI-07-C-0230 Highly conformal radiation improves the ability to spare normal tissues. Helical tomotherapy is an emerging highly conformal radiation delivery method which provides megavoltage CT localization and may provide superior conformality and localization compared to other dynamic intensity modulated radiation therapy techniques. We have recently obtained a helical tomotherapy unit in our department and would like to establish a program for treating metastatic disease with highly conformal therapies. Metastatic disease is often treated to less than ablative doses due to its proximity to critical structures and concern for inducing toxicity. Newer conformal therapies offer the ability to escalate radiation dose delivered to oligometastases while minimizing both dose delivered to normal tissue and toxicity." Eligibility up to 4 metastases, the largest no more than 5 cm.  The study treats ALL the metastases, up to a limit of 4.  They won't take you if you have mre than 4 mets.  I tried to get in on this study, but was rejected because my largest met is more than 5 cm.  Maybe someone here can put my research to good use. Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2011 01:23AM 33skidoo wrote: I LOVE Inverness.  Lived in Gainesville for 10 years and miss it.  You are in a good place for state of the art treatment.  You could also go to the Moffitt Cancer Center in Tampa for a 2nd opinion or consult if you want.  I did hormonal treatments only (and radiation to my spine) for 3 1/2 years before I got progression and started chemo.  But then, I'm her2-.  Maybe chemo works better with the herceptin than hormonals.  Or maybe your cancer load is low enough that they think they might get you to NED (no evidence of disease) if they hit it hard at first.  We all hope for an affair with NED.  Reggie or the Stable Boy are good guys too.  If you do a consult at a major cancer center, you can still get your treatment with a local doctor, otherwise the travel gets to be a bit of a grind. It will take a while to get your head wrapped around this.   Don't get too caught up in the treatment that you forget to live.  Get out and have some fun!

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2013 11:44PM 33skidoo wrote: Hi Judie.  Hope you get some good relief from the rads soon.  I've had rads several times and got different results each time.  Got really quick relief on my spinal mets but later it took a lot longer for relief when I had mets in hip radiated.  Still, I did eventually get complete pain relief from the rads.  I also got a round of steroids recently to treat inflammation and it really helped.  I was also reluctant to take them but decided I'd rather have steroid side effects than continue with the pain and inflammation.  Sorry you are having to take a chemo break over the white count.  I took a 6 week break to get my white cell count back up.  Fortunately I didn't backslide any while on the break.  Hopefully some good quality sleep and pain relief will have you feeling like new.  Lots of love from me too! Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2010 01:20AM 33skidoo wrote: Lisa, You might consider having a lumpectomy of the breast tumor if it is suitable for that sort of treatment.  I had an "excisional biopsy" which was really a lumpectomy, and very happy with my outcome.  My breast tumor was fairly small, and other than a thin faint scar, my breast looks normal.  With my systematic hormonal treatment, I have not had any recurrence of the tumor in 2 1/2 years.  Your onc may be less resistant to a lumpectomy rather than a mastectomy.  Recovery was a breeze for me.

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2012 05:20PM 33skidoo wrote: bone scans don't show "lytic" mets, which are essentially holes in bones.  They do show "blastic" mets, which are areas where additional bone is laid down.  Bone scans (and PET scans) can be misleading as areas that are healing will show up on the scan.

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2013 11:36AM - edited Jan 9, 2013 11:37AM by 33skidoo Sorry you have  joined our club.  That being said, I love it here.  Lots of fellowship and good advice.  I started out stage IV from the beginning with bone mets more than 4 years ago.  I had a CT guided bone biopsy to my hip with local anesthetic only.  The radiologist did it.  It was a piece of cake.  They went at me from the front.  I also have spine and rib mets and didn't have any problem laying down thru the procedure.  Slight sting when I got the local, some pressure while he screwed the medieval torture looking device into me (don't look if it will freak you out), nothing I would call pain, and I wasn't even sore afterward.
